intro: Phoradendron buxifolium, commonly known as the waxleaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Viscaceae family. It is native to the southeastern United States and thrives on a variety of host trees, including oaks and elms. The plant has small, thick, waxy leaves that are dark green on top and whitish underneath, providing it with a distinctive appearance. It produces small, white or pale green flowers that are followed by red, fleshy berries. The berries are an important food source for birds, which in turn help disperse its seeds.
